bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, November 18, 1952

div1.p: Hench discusses travel preparations for his trip to the dedication of Camp Lazear. Hanberry is hesitant to attend because of financial difficulties. Hench includes a list of names of dignitaries who should receive invitations to the ceremony.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, November 18, 1952
div1.opener:
November 18, 1952
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
Marti 219, Marianao
Havana, Cuba
My dear Pedro:
div1.p:
I am delighted with the progress of your plans. I am particularly happy
that the patrons of the project have seen fit to preserve the name Camp
Lazear and Building No. 1.

According to present plans, I will fly down the night of Sunday, November
30 and will arrive early Monday morning, on the plane from Miami. I will
let you know the exact hour later. I think the plane arrives between
7 and 8 a.m. I hate to have you bother to come to the airport but I leave
that up to you as I know your welcoming nature.

I am working on my little talk. I will stay within the eight to ten minute
time limit. If at all possible, I will send it to you even before I leave
here. Otherwise I will bring some copies with me and will have it trans-
lated into Spanish here so as to save you time. Rest assured, Pedro, that
there will be nothing contentious in my talk. I will merely pay my homage
to Finlay and Delgado and then in turn to the members of the Reed Commis-
sion, pointing out that they made together a magnificent team and a wonder-
ful contribution to humanity. If, when you see my talk you, knowing the
Cuban temperament as you do, think I should change a word here or a sentence
there, I shall be happy to have your suggestions.

My colleagues of the Mayo Clinic are most interested in the dedication.
Therefore I am coming to Cuba not as a personal individual but as a repre-
sentative of the Mayo Clinic and Mayo Foundation. The Mayo Foundation would
like to honor Doctor Finlay and have authorized me, if it is consistent with
your thinking and planning of the program, to place a wreath beneath the
medallion of Finlay, perhaps during the ceremony. Would that be appropriate?
It could be either during the ceremony, and only take a minute, or if this
interruption seems inappropriate I could place it before the ceremony. How-
ever I think it might be nicer if it would be possible for me to do it during
the ceremony. Again, I will abide by the decision of yourself and your col-
leagues.

I have just had a disturbing letter from Hanberry saying that he has decided
he cannot go to Cuba, partly because of his advanced age and partly because
of finances. I don't know whether he has heard from you, but at your sug-
gestion I wrote him, telling him that he would be receiving a special in-
vitation from you and hinting that at least his expenses would be paid by
his Cuban hosts. I remember when he came to Washington he was attended by
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
- 2 -
November 18, 1952
a young nephew. Perhaps he is “afraid” to travel alone. Perhaps this
declining of your invitation is temporary and perhaps he could still be
persuaded to come if his Cuban hosts could afford to have a young relative
come with him to take care of him. As he is the only surviving volunteer
his presence would add much to the ceremony. I wired him yesterday, asking
him to tell me frankly whether he could go if a relative attended him. I
made no commitments as far as expenses were concerned.

Lambert has moved from the address I gave you. Hanberry has given me the
new address which is as follows: Mr. Gust E. Lambert, 17092 Lincoln Street,
Hazel Crest, Illinois. I have written him also, asking him to get in touch
with you directly and to send you a glossy photograph.

Pedro, I fear that I have been inefficient in helping you and should have
sent you a much larger list of Americans to whom official invitations
should have been sent. I have hardly ever been as busy in my life as I
have been the last three months, hence my preoccupation and my imperfect
help to you, for which I apologize.

The names of other important personages and individuals in this country who
will be greatly interested in the dedication of Camp Lazear, and to whom
invitations should be sent I give you herewith. I leave it to you and your
colleagues whether they should be sent. It is still not too late, providing
they are sent air mail and it may well be that some of these people will
come in person or that the institutions will send representatives.

list.item:
Dr. Louis H. Bauer, President of the American Medical Association.
131 Fulton Avenue, Hempstead, Long Island, New York

Dr. Edward James McCormick, President-Elect of the American
Medical Association
402 Madison Avenue, Toledo, Ohio

Dr. Elmer Henderson, past-President of the American Medical Associa-
tion, who was in Cuba last January.
606 South 4th Street, Louisville, Kentucky

Dr. G. K. Strode, Director of International Health Division,

Dr. Fred L. Soper, International Health Division, Rockefeller

Dr. Wilton L. Halverson, President of the American Public Health

760 Market Street, San Francisco 2, California

His Excellency, the U. S. Ambassador to Cuba, American Embassy,
Havana.

item.p:
Category 2 - Yellow Fever Personalities and their relatives.
Mrs. Jessie Daniel Ames, (who is hoping actually to attend the ceremony;
why not have her unveil the one tablet on which her husband's
name appears?) Wren's Nest, Tryon, North Carolina
Dr. D. L. Andrus (physician-son of the yellow fever volunteer Andrus,
now deceased).
805 Cooper Street, Camden, New Jersey
Mrs. W. D. Briggs (Dr. Lazear's daughter whom he never saw, born in
the U.S. just before he died in Cuba), 106 The Uplands, Berkeley,
California.
Admiral and Mrs. James O. Gawne (She is Lazear's first cousin and very
interested in Camp Lazear), 2439 Tracy Place, Washington, D.C.
Dr. L. O. Howard (the famous American entomologist who helped Reed
and Lazear identify the mosquitoes with which they were working.)
c/o Miss Lucy Howard, 45 Pondfield Road, Bronxville, New York.
Mrs. Merritt W. Ireland, (widow of General Ireland, long-time Surgeon
General of the U. S. Army who was in Cuba so often.)
1870 Wyoming Avenue N.W., Washington, D. C.
Mr. William Houston Lazear (Lazear's son), P.O. Box 812, Santa Barbara,
California.
Mr. Adrian Macia (former owner of Camp Lazear, who has been so gracious
to me through the years and who has been so interested in Camp
Lazear), Manzana de Gomez 325, Havana.
Mrs. Charles P. Orr (Lazear's cousin, greatly interested in Camp Lazear),
6101 Howe Street, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.
Prof. James E. Peabody (the retired biology professor who put through
Congress the bills honoring Reed et al, presenting the Congres-
sional Medal, and so on),
75 Linden Street, Brattleboro, Vermont.
Mr. and Mrs. Crosby Roper (She was Laura Wood who wrote a biography
of Reed)
2151 California Street N.W., Washington, D. C.
Miss Frances B. Seth, 4511 Windsor Mill Road, Woodlawn, Baltimore, Maryland.
(Lazear's first cousin).
Mr. John R. Taylor (in 1900 a U. S. Army non-commissioned officer who,
I believe served as a laboratory technician at Los Animas hos-
pital and knew well the yellow fever personalities.)
548 Grand Avenue, Upper Darby, Pennsylvania

With the exception of Mrs. Ames, I doubt if any of these people will be able
to come because of their advanced age or other reasons. Nevertheless it
would be extremely courteous if they could receive an invitation.

It has occurred to me belatedly that much American friendship toward Cuba
and Doctor Finlay can be engendered by inviting the deans of the medical
schools from which the yellow fever “heroes” or personalities obtained their
medical degrees.

list.item:
Dr. George A. Bennett, Dean of Jefferson Medical College, Philadelphia
Pennsylvania, from which Doctor Finlay received his medical
degree in 1855.

Dr. Vernon W. Lippard, Dean of the Medical School, University of Virginia,
Charlottesville, Virginia, from which Walter Reed obtained his
first medical degree in 1869, General Kean received his medical
degree in 1883 and which Johnny Moran attended.

Dr. Currier McEwen, Dean of the Bellevue Medical Center, New York
University, 477 First Avenue, New York, New York, from which
Reed obtained his second medical degree in 1870.

Dr. H. Boyd Wylie, Dean of the Medical School, University of Maryland,
Baltimore, Maryland, from which Doctor Carroll received his
degree in 1891.

Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, Dean of the Medical School (College of Physicians
and Surgeons) Columbia University, New York City, from which
Doctors Agramonte and Lazear both received their medical degree
in 1892 and General Sternberg in 1860.

Dr. George P. Berry, Dean of the Medical School, Harvard University,
Boston, Massachusetts, from which General Wood received his
medical degree in 1884.

div1.p:
I do think that these institutions would greatly appreciate an official
invitation and if they cannot send someone, some of them may at least have
medical or non-medical alumni living in Havana who might attend.

Pedro, could you save for me and either send to me here or give me in Havana,
about 50 invitations that I may send to the surviving relatives of other
yellow fever volunteers and other Americans greatly interested in the con-
quest of yellow fever.

I am anxious to know from what institution Doctor Delgado received his medi-
cal degree. It is difficult to find anything about him. Could you send me
this information?

Thank you so much for the photographs which arrived this morning. They are
wonderful to have. Also, I am greatly relieved that you were able to use
some of the old wood and that you have saved some of the rest of it for me
to bring back for souvenirs. I am making arrangements with the U. S. Customs
so that it can be shipped to me without difficulty.

Do you need a title for my little talk at the dedication? Will it be used
on a program? If it is too late to send you a title and yet my name is to
appear, perhaps you can merely say “Remarks - - Dr. P. S. Hench, Mayo
Foundation.” By the way, is President Batista coming?

I will be delighted to stay over for the ceremony in the Academy of Science
at 9 p.m., Wednesday evening, December 3, for which I shall bring my
dinner jacket and Finlay Decoration. General Streit telephoned me, and
is looking forward with enthusiasm to the Cuban visit.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
